docs.lead_paragraph: Many medical groups and women's advocates have for years been concerned about what they call a gender gap in health coverage: Although health plans generally cover prescription drugs, most exclude contraceptives, which results in more out-of-pocket expenses for women than for men. But a closely watched effort in California to change coverage plans appears headed for defeat.

headline.main: Effort to Cover Contraception Likely to Fail

docs.abstract: Many medical groups and women's advocates have for years been concerned about what they call gender gap in health coverage: although health plans generally cover prescription drugs, most exclude contraceptives, which results in more out-of-pocket expenses for women than for men; but a closely watched effort in California to change coverage plans appears headed for defeat; Gov Pete Wilson must decide whether to sign legislation requiring health plans that cover prescription drugs to cover many contraceptives as well; Wilson spokesman says that Wilson is leaning strongly toward a veto (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: ''I'm the oldest of the baby boomers,'' President Clinton told a fund-raising gathering in Miami a couple of months ago. ''I'm what you'd call near-elderly.'' That locution was evidently being bruited about the White House at the time, because the President in January announced a proposal to extend Government health insurance to people as young as 55. ''The three million uninsured people in this group,'' wrote John M. Broder in The New York Times, ''known by insurance statisticians as the 'near elderly,' are too young for Medicare.''

headline.main: On Language; Don't Call Me 'Near Elderly'

docs.abstract: William Safire On Language article discusses age euphemism 'nearly elderly' and varying meanings of 'if;' drawing (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: PROPELLED by forces no one really controls, the nation has arrived at a point at which sensational news is crossed by throbbing, tangled skeins of gossip, titillation, rumor, speculation and revulsion. Beginning with the O. J. Simpson case and continuing through the death of Diana, Princess of Wales, to the current fulminations of the White House sex scandal, a ritual has evolved that strictly governs the unfolding of a certain kind of Big Story.

headline.main: The Nation; The News Junkies' Treatment Program

docs.abstract: Ritual has evolved in news media governing coverage of certain type of Big Story; is characterized by manic attention to stories about celebrities and/or sexual behavior, followed immediately by condemnation, severe guilt, group recrimination and feelings of inadequacy; coverage of White House sex scandal and other recent issues noted; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: It was just a tension headache, the kind that sends you to bed early. But by morning, the throbbing had traveled down Laurie Anne Frank's back and, as she washed her face, she realized she could not feel the water. By that November evening in 1996, every inch of her body felt like a pincushion pricked by some invisible demon. ''There's a nasty flu going around,'' her doctor explained after an examination. ''Nothing a few days in bed won't take care of.''

headline.main: The Neediest Cases; Sent Into Tailspin by a Deadly Illness, an Actress Battles Back

docs.abstract: Laurie Anne Frank, an actress who is recovering from a rare nerve disorder, is being helped by Community Service Society of New York, one of the charities supported by The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: MARKETS S.& P. Leads the Way The stock market breezed past another big round figure, with the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index breaking 1,000 for the first time. That left the index at double its level three years ago. It has been Wall Street's recent star, far outpacing the Dow Jones industrial average, which began to underperform around the time that Asian economic worries emerged. ''The S.& P. gives a greater weight to defensive stock groups like drugs and foods and beverages,'' which are less vulnerable if the economy weakens, said Richard McCabe, chief market analyst for Merrill Lynch. The S.& P. ended at 1,012.45, up 25.04 points for the week, and the Dow continued to rally to 8,189.49, up 282.99 points on the week. With the Dow near its record, it seems to have a good foothold for a climb into a new range, one technical analyst said.
docs.abstract: Diary of last week's events affecting financial markets and the economy; photos
